lines.text: Enter Clown, and PAROLLES, following

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Good Monsieur Lavache, give my Lord Lafeu this letter: I have ere now, sir, been better known to you, when I have held familiarity with fresher clothes but I am now, sir, muddied in fortunes mood, and smell somewhat strong of her strong displeasure.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Truly, fortunes displeasure is but sluttish, if it smell so strongly as thou speakest of: I will henceforth eat no fish of fortunes buttering. Prithee, allow the wind.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Nay, you need not to stop your nose, sir I spake but by a metaphor.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Indeed, sir, if your metaphor stink, I will stop my nose or against any mans metaphor. Prithee, get thee further.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Pray you, sir, deliver me this paper.

lines.speaker: clown
lines.text: Foh! prithee, stand away: a paper from fortunes closestool to give to a nobleman! Look, here he comes himself. Here is a purr of fortunes, sir, or of fortunes cat,but not a muskcat,that has fallen into the unclean fishpond of her displeasure, and, as he says, is muddied withal: pray you, sir, use the carp as you may for he looks like a poor, decayed, ingenious, foolish, rascally knave. I do pity his distress in my similes of comfort and leave him to your lordship.
Enter LAFEU
Exit

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: My lord, I am a man whom fortune hath cruelly scratched.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: And what would you have me to do Tis too late to pare her nails now. Wherein have you played the knave with fortune, that she should scratch you, who of herself is a good lady and would not have knaves thrive long under her Theres a quart decu for you: let the justices make you and fortune friends: I am for other business.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I beseech your honour to hear me one single word.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: You beg a single penny more: come, you shall hat save your word.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: My name, my good lord, is Parolles.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: You beg more than word, then. Cox my passion! give me your hand. How does your drum

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: O my good lord, you were the first that found me!

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Was I, in sooth and I was the first that lost thee.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: It lies in you, my lord, to bring me in some grace, for you did bring me out.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Out upon thee, knave! dost thou put upon me at once both the office of God and the devil One brings thee in grace and the other brings thee out. The kings coming I know by his trumpets. Sirrah, inquire further after me I had talk of you last night: though you are a fool and a knave, you shall eat go to, follow.
Trumpets sound

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I praise God for you.
Exeunt
